user_input: How can a postgraduate student request an extension or deferring an assessment if they are struggling with their workload or facing unexpected emergencies?
reference_contexts: | Support process | Use this if | What this covers | | ------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [ Delayed Assessment Scheme](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/student-support-and-wellbeing/student-support-framework#Delayed-Assessment-Scheme) | You need a small amount of flexibility to help you manage your wellbeing, student life, and workload due to reasons which are not grounds for evidenced EC's. | Taught students have a maximum of 3 Delayed Assessment Permits to use during the year. Each permit grants you a set mitigation such as a 5 working day extension or deferral. There are no minimum grounds, but you should think carefully before using your permit. Make sure to review the restrictions of the scheme, and note that not all assessments are eligible. | | [ Short-term Illness and other Extenuating Circumstances](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/student-support-and-wellbeing/student-support-framework#Extenuating-Circumstances) | You have a short-term illness, bereavement or other unexpected emergency. Normally you must provide evidence. | 'Extenuating Circumstances' (often know as 'ECs') are events which are sudden, unexpected, significantly disruptive and beyond your control and which may affect your performance at summative assessment, such as a serious illness or the death of a close relative. You can submit an Extenuating Circumstances claim to access 'mitigation' such as an extension or deferring an assessment to a later date. | | [
reference: A postgraduate student can request an extension or deferring an assessment through two main support processes. If they need a small amount of flexibility for reasons not covered by evidenced Extenuating Circumstances, they can use the Delayed Assessment Scheme, which allows up to 3 permits per year, each granting a set mitigation such as a 5 working day extension or deferral. If the student is experiencing a short-term illness, bereavement, or other unexpected emergency, they can submit an Extenuating Circumstances claim, usually with evidence, to access mitigation such as an extension or deferring an assessment to a later date.

reference: The Delayed Assessment Scheme is intended for situations where a student needs a small amount of flexibility to help manage their wellbeing, student life, and workload due to reasons that are not grounds for evidenced Extenuating Circumstances (ECs). There are no minimum grounds required to use a permit, but students are advised to think carefully before using one. It is important to review the restrictions of the scheme, as not all assessments are eligible for this scheme.

reference_contexts: Reasonable Adjustments for Disabilities and Long-term Conditions](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/student-support-and-wellbeing/student-support-framework#Reasonable-Adjustments) | You have a disability or long-term physical or mental health condition. | UCL can provide longer-term 'Reasonable Adjustments' to support your learning and assessment. This includes setting up a 'SoRA' (Summary of Reasonable Adjustments) with UCL's Student Support and Wellbeing team. | | [ Academic Adjustments](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/student-support-and-wellbeing/student-support-framework#Academic-Adjustments) | You need long-term or ongoing support with one or more of the following: You or your partner is pregnant or planning maternity, paternity or adoption leave; You are a parent or carer; You observe religious beliefs or cultural customs; You are affected by any form of harassment or discrimination; You are affected by traumatic world events such as war or terrorism; You are a critical worker (e.g. NHS staff). | Academic Adjustments include long-term reasonable adjustments arranged by your Department if you need additional support with learning, teaching and assessment | | [
reference: If you have a disability or long-term physical or mental health condition, UCL's Student Support and Wellbeing team can provide longer-term Reasonable Adjustments to support your learning and assessment, including setting up a Summary of Reasonable Adjustments (SoRA). Academic Adjustments are also available for those needing long-term or ongoing support due to circumstances such as pregnancy, caring responsibilities, religious observance, experiences of harassment or discrimination, or being affected by traumatic world events. These adjustments are arranged by your Department to provide additional support with learning, teaching, and assessment.

user_input: wut happns if i hav to do a resit for a module i faild?
reference_contexts: Where a student fails one or more modules at the first attempt and is not eligible for condonement, then they will be required to undertake reassessment of the failed modules. Depending on the amount of failure, how many credits' worth of modules, reassessment may be in the form of a resit or a repeat: - Where a student is required to resit a module, they will be reassessed in its failed components at the next occasion, typically in the late summer assessment period. - Where a student is required to repeat a module, they will take the module in the next academic year and complete reassessment in all its components. - Where a postgraduate taught student fails in their dissertation/ research project, they will normally resit by the end of January. Exceptionally, the Board of Examiners may decide that the extent of failure is such that the student will need to repeat the dissertation with tuition and fees. Arrangements for reassessment of intercollegiate modules taken as part of a UCL programme will be determined by the responsible UCL Board of Examiners. The marks for modules in which students have undertaken second attempts will be capped at the module pass mark (40.00% for modules at FHEQ levels 4, 5 and 6; 50.00% for modules at FHEQ level 7.) - [
reference: If you are required to resit a module you failed, you will be reassessed in its failed components at the next occasion, typically in the late summer assessment period. The marks for modules in which you have undertaken second attempts will be capped at the module pass mark (50.00% for modules at FHEQ level 7).

reference: If a postgraduate student fails one or more modules at the first attempt and is not eligible for condonement, they will be required to undertake reassessment of the failed modules. The form of reassessment depends on the amount of failure and the number of credits failed. Reassessment may be either a resit or a repeat. If a student is required to resit a module, they will be reassessed in its failed components at the next occasion, typically in the late summer assessment period. If a student is required to repeat a module, they will take the module again in the next academic year and complete reassessment in all its components. If a postgraduate taught student fails their dissertation or research project, they will normally resit by the end of January, but in exceptional cases, the Board of Examiners may require the student to repeat the dissertation with tuition and fees. For intercollegiate modules taken as part of a UCL programme, reassessment arrangements will be determined by the responsible UCL Board of Examiners. Marks for modules in which students have undertaken second attempts will be capped at the module pass mark, which is 40.00% for modules at FHEQ levels 4, 5, and 6, and 50.00% for modules at FHEQ level 7.

user_input: What does UCL expect regarding informal resolution before a student submits a formal complaint?
reference_contexts: Many complaints can be resolved at an informal or local level without needing to submit a formal complaint. Students can speak to their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental or Faculty Tutor, Course Representative, or Research Student Representative if they have any concerns about their programme. They can also speak to the Students' Union's Advice Service. UCL strongly encourages this kind of resolution and does expect students to have attempted some form of informal resolution before making a formal complaint. |
reference: UCL expects students to have attempted some form of informal resolution before making a formal complaint.

reference: The final transcript is an official transcript of final confirmed module results (marks and grades). It is available to graduates following conferral of an award by the UCL Education Committee. The final transcript is issued as a hard copy via post to the student's registered home address as held in Portico. Degree certificates and final transcripts, detailing examinations taken and results achieved, will be issued within 3 months from the date the award is conferred by UCL authorities.

reference: Transcripts of results are official records of your confirmed module results (marks and grades). If you have confirmed module results, you can request a digital 'e-transcript' via the UCL Online Store after UCL Academic Services releases your results. You can get one free copy per year of study once you have been notified of your confirmed results. If you are still a student and have not finished your course, you can only get a transcript if your results are confirmed. If you do not have confirmed results yet, you cannot get a transcript. Affiliate transcripts are issued automatically to home institutions. Final transcripts (hard copy) are only available to graduates after your award is conferred and will be sent to your home address within 3 months of the award date.

reference: An academic reference is a personal academic reference, usually from a Personal Tutor or Project Supervisor. You can request it digitally via the relevant referee. It is available to students with confirmed module results, including affiliates, and graduates. An academic reference may include details of confirmed module results, provisional or conferred award, and summary details of a student's achievement within a cohort, such as being in the top 10%. References should not include a student's rank order within their cohort. Any module results and programme outcomes are provisional until confirmed by the responsible Board of Examiners, and any recommended award is provisional until conferred by UCL Education Committee. If your full set of module results is not available, confirmation of results and conferral of any award may be delayed.
